"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/548fc74b6368723d7a530700#post_548fc74b6368723d7a530700
Not only that, it just felt really harsh. 

The Thompson abuse isn't funny to me, and for some reason it feels like they wanted it to be the glue that holds the group of teens together. Seeing your friend constantly putting himself through abuse shouldn't be the way your friends bond.

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/548fc8ba63687250a7cd0000#post_548fc8ba63687250a7cd0000
Still, even though it wasn't the best episode (in fact I'd say it was the worst yet), The Love God felt like the only truly _bad_ episode so far. Sure, there were a few "meh" episodes, but nothing this bad.

And it's made even worse seeing as how it's the last episode currently aired, and it's been what, 2 or 3 weeks now? And nothing else has even been confirmed for the future? So we're just gonna be left on that oddly sour note.

topics.body:
"@EHAN":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/548fcba16368720e0f830f00#post_548fcba16368720e0f830f00

I think that part of why the don't share that is because they would get  alot of pressure into writing and that would make some of the jokes or the plot to feel forced.

The amount of detail/foreshadowing the show has feels so natural because the creator(s) take their time to adress each one of them and give the attention it deserves.

If you have a deadline, that means pressure and because you need to finish the story, you forget several details that were supposed to be there and stuff like that.

At least that's what I think.

topics.body:
OH on the topic of puppies

I've recently signed up to volunteer to help out at a place that raises service dogs for people with PTSD or diabetes or other similar ailments

So basically my job is to cuddle these tiny two-week old Labrador puppies for an hour to "get them used to human interaction"
